title: What are examples of myths? - Quora

response.answer_text: Myths are stories that in their essence center around truth. Myths seek to embody an explanation of larger questions that faced ancient people. In addition to the daily question of ‘where is my next meal coming from?’ they also asked such questions as ‘how did the world begin?’ and ‘where did we come from?’ – likely as they watched the skies and pondered the heavens. Ancient peoples sought understandable and creative ways to explain the unexplainable, with creation myths like the Norse story of Odin. Often referred to as All-Father Odin, he and his brothers killed Ymir, the first being in Norse mythology and father of all giants. They made the world (called Midgard) from his body and man from tree trunks to populate this new world. A collection of pre-Christian poems called the Eddas describes the earth’s creation this way. From Ymir’s flesh the earth was created,And from his sweat [or blood] the sea,Mountains from bone,Trees from hair,And from his skull the sky. And from his eyebrows the blithe gods madeMidgard, home of the sons of menAnd from his brainsThey sculpted the grim clouds. – from Sources - Norse Mythology for Smart People It is noteworthy that the Biblical book of Genesis mentions a race of giants. Myths are also an attempt to explain how or why natural events occur, as with tales of an ancient flood that virtually destroys the world. Such an example is the Sumerian epic of Gilgamesh as well as the Biblical flood weathered by Noah, his family, and pairs of creatures who survive the flood by riding it out in the ark. The older epic of Gilgamesh and the story of Noah are quite similar, even down to the instructions on building the boat.
